instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
This was working off battery only but wouldn't charge. Looked like something was on board that shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> to ground pin nearby. REplaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and DCIN Fuse. I've changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> 4 times now after replacing it short will be gone on pin 1 but if I plug charger in long it will burn <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> fairly quickly. I've checked the traces from <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and all has good traces. Tried replacing ISL at the same time as <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> but no luck. Any chance the coil L7130 could cause this? Seems like I've seen this before.

Diode at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is .138

ISL voltages and resistance look ok other than 18,17,27,28 of course are low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Be sure about both R/<CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and their traces/solders to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.
Also check diode mode to ground directly on the Gate pins of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: TRaces all check out and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 is 625 and pin 6 is .465 once <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is replaced and before powering board. If I power the board with magsafe only, Pin 1 will be somewhere around .03 range. Could <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> cause it to be burning up? I feel like that is the only major change since I started working on the board unless I shorted something unknowingly checking test points or bad solder on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. I say that because originally this board booted off battery and currently that would not be the case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: I tried swapping <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> again prior to powering board but no luck. Diode at pin 1 <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is now .15 after plugging in charger. Pin 6 is still .465

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Why do you insist so much to check diode mode on the MOSFET Gates, after applying power?
This is totally irrelvant; it may come to normal values after few minutes.
If <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> detects a problem, will force off corresponding <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> section shorting G-S pins; inside the chip, on the output driver.
When in doubt, remove the MOSFET and check it outside of the board.

Board still works on battery alone?
Did you check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Ahhhh ok. Got it. Board still starts with battery. 

Yes resistance is good.
Pin 17/18 -3.5 ohms
27/28 - 20.0 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Did you check out of board if any of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> removed got really burnt?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: After checking the chips off the board it doesn't appear they did. I thought low value I was getting on pin 1 was indicative. <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and DCIN fuse are only things I know for certain were broken to start with.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: OK, then no danger to connect charger and post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
1- 0
2- 16V
3- 4V
9 - 0V
12 - 3.4V
13 - 3.2V
14 - 3.2V
15 - 0
17 - 1.2V
19 - 5.5V
20 - 5.5V
27 - 1.2V

I've changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> multiple times and same results. I've tested traces from <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> also

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Post <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86 resistance value; measured onboard, ohm scale.
Check their traces.
Also check continuity between <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/1/5/6 all measure correctly and I have checked for continuity from all points of <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> to the according traced points on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Can you post what I asked???

"1- 0"
One of mentioned resistors, or <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> is bad; as MOSFET is driven on, but you don't get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keeps blowing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Thanks for your help. I DID figure this out. I pulled <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> again and under the scope when touching up those pads on the board again there was a little thin layer of pink plastic ribbon on one of the pads. I looked at the bottom of <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and there is a thin layer of pink plastic that was partially damaged and shifted. So I believe when I was pulling them and placing, I used too much heat that was causing that pink layer to get partially damaged. After cleaning up the bottom of <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and touching up the pads on it with some solder prior to placing it back, the board now starts every time. From now on when I change a <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> I will use less heat and check the bottom prior to placing it on the board! Oy what a headache.
